Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative EAGER project: Early Career Seismic Chief Scientist Training Cruise
Award.AbstractNarration:
Results of the recent UNOLS Marine Seismic Questionnaire (MSQ) demonstrate the value of an early
career scientist Multi-Channel Seismic (MCS) chief scientist training cruise. Proposed, and awarded, are funds to carry out
a MCS training program that includes 4 days of seismic data acquisition to increase the number of early career scientists
experienced in marine seismology and to demonstrate the value of the Scripps Institution of
Oceanography portable MCS system, a UNOLS facility. The training program consists of three parts: (i)
Webinars prior to the cruise to expose the participants to the fundamentals of active source marine
seismology, to provide the scientific background needed to plan the upcoming survey effectively, and to
introduce the participants to open source processing and interpretation tools. The Webinars will include
Proposal Writing and Data Management training. Applications will be solicited, including a maximum 2-
page science proposal, after the webinar series. Once selected, participants will discuss their cruise plans
with the PI team prior to the pre-cruise workshop via several telepresence meetings; then, during a 2-day
workshop immediately before the cruise, the participants will finalize the cruise plan under the PI team's
guidance; (ii) A training cruise. Each participant will contribute to the entire team walking off the ship
with post-stack time migrated data, as well as writing a cruise report collaboratively; and (iii) a 2-day data
interpretation workshop with computer-based visualization software.
Intellectual Merit:
The proposed survey regions are on the active continental margin of the west coast of the United States,
where a variety of sedimentary and tectonic settings are available, providing targets of interest to a wide
range of participants. At the extended continental margin off the coast of Oregon, the seismic reflection
profiles acquired, processed, and archived from this cruise can be used to image the subducting plate and
the Astoria Fan, as well as accretionary ridges hosting gas hydrate and pockets of hemipelagic sediment
containing paleo-oceanographic information. Targets have implications for addressing important
societally relevant questions, such as earthquake hazards and paleoclimate records in basins. There will
also be potential for using seismic techniques to reveal real-time, fine-scale within the water column
around upwelling regions of the northeastern Pacific Ocean boundaries. Open access data from this cruise
can augment on-going and near-future science conducted by a broader community.
Broader Impacts:
For this novel, transformative project, early-career scientists will be selected from a wide applicant pool.
This science mission will be advertised on the MSQ and other geoscience listservs, and encouraged participations
of underrepresented minorities and women by promoting the opportunity via organizations such as
Society for Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Scienceand Earth Science
Women's Network. Participants will gain not only first-hand seismic cruise experience but also
experience communicating their research to non-scientists. The proposed activities will be used to inform
the public about the unique and essential contributions of seismic research toward solving a variety of
important societal challenges. Results will be shared on the AGU's GeoSpace blog and Instagram
account. Important deliverables from the pre-cruise and onboard activities to the community are to
establish and provide "cookbook" of the open source software used during this cruise; and make the data
acquired from the cruise open immediately as soon as they are archived at the publically accessible
archives. A post-cruise survey will be conducted in collaboration with the UNOLS office to obtain
feedback from the participants and encourage the participants to write NSF proposals, the number of
which will be the direct and ultimate measurement of the success of this ECS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project conducted an  academic multichannel seismic (MCS) training program in order to: (1) increase the number of early career scientists experienced in marine seismology; (2) increase the visibility and use cases of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) portable MCS system; and (3) demonstrate its value as a UNOLS national asset. Our science target was Cascadia continental margin, which is located off the State of Oregon coast and known as the region with seismogenic/tsunamigenic risks to a broader public. The 15-day training program that consists with pre-cruise (3 days webiners, 2 day web cruise-planning conference, 2 days workshop); during-cruise (7 days); and post-cruise (1 day workshop).

Pre-cruise stage:
We have convened pre-cruise preparation with prospective participants in April 2017 providing a publicly opened webinar series over three consecutive afternoon hours. This webiners educated nearly 100 registrants every session about a wider variety of topics that enable one to prepare how to propose new science expedition and discovery ideas using UNOLS Academic Fleet, including the SIO portable MCS system. The topics included science related to Cascadia seismogenic continental margin; introduction to US Academic Research Fleet systems; introduction to National Science Foundation proposal submissions process; and introduction to academic multichannel seismics projects. We successfully have selected a total of 19 early career scientists (from MS and PhD student, to postdocs, and to university faculty/assistant professor level; male:female = 10:9). All the participants, grouped into 4 depending on geographical locations of their science objectives,  have then communicated with PIs and they have determined the cruise plan. The three PIs and the 19 early career scientists, as well as 2 postdoc mentors (who are seismic experts; male: female= 1:1) have convened 1.5 day pre-cruise workshop at the port of Newport, OR, immediately before the cruise, to further learn public engagement through their science effort. This workshop was lead by a professional science writer and we all were trained to think how to communicate with public in writing, SNSs, etc., using COMPASS message box model, to best engage ourselves with the NSF?s Broader Impact. 

During-cruise stage:
We have conducted 7-days MCS survey designed by the 19 early career scientists. They were grouped into 3 different shift schedule to continuously carry out the survey around the clock, 24/7, to maximize science data acquisition. Each shift had a designated ?chief scientist?, ?co-chief scientist?, ?event logger?, ?seismic processor?,?seismic watchstander?, and ?underway data processor? in the group to optimize the opportunity of active learning to take leadership in charge during a research expedition. Throughout a shift, designated chief scientist made operation decisions while closely communications with officers at the pilot house, science support service group, and other participants. At the end of expedition, we have acquired a total of approx. 770km of seismic data and shipboard underway geophysics data from the unmapped area within Cascadia seismogenic margin. 
During the cruise, all the early career participants had to work on the blog post on what they desired to convey to engage public to their science effort (http://csw.unols.org/scientist-posts/). Some of them were translated into Spanish by one of the participants (also posted on the American Geophysical Union Blogosphere: https://blogs.agu.org/thefield/2017/10/13/de-estudiante-de-geofisica-jefe-cientifico-por-un-dia/). 
Post-cruise stage:
All the data became open to public access as we have proposed after the quality assessment of the data was completed (doi: 10.1594/IEDA/500194). A total of 15 out of 19 early career participants have answered post cruise research activities (as of October 15th 2018, approximately 1 year from the completion of the proposed program), including: 67% of them used the data from this expedition for their thesis research, classroom presentation, teaching materials, conference papers, and department seminars. 60% of them are planning to use the data for publications in 2018-2020 timeline and for proposals, including scientific drilling effort to better understand the seismogetnic/tsunamigenic risk of the Cascadia Margin.
